history.content:
The way I did was to run it on a free instance of AWS. Because bearmaps is actually a server you cant just embed it on your website statically. Then take the local port running bear maps and use something like ngrok to create a url that can be access from the public internet. 

Also this way the server code (class or java) cannot be accessed.

The way I did was to run it on a free instance of AWS. Because bearmaps is actually a server you cant just embed it on your website statically. Then take the local port running bear maps and use something like ngrok to create a url that can be access from the public internet.

children.subject: From CS61B Piazza: "The instances you should be using are free, but only for 750 hours a month. Since our BearMaps Quilt spec boots two machines, that means you have about 2 weeks of free usage on those machines. After that time passes, Amazon may start charging you for any hours over 750 each month." So, the amount of time you have free is cut in half because it uses two machines.

So don't use Quilt. Quilt is just an infrastructure that makes it easier to set up a distributed system. It actually gives no advantage to your task of just demoing your BearMaps. It was used in class b/c 1) its slightly easier to set up 2) introduces students to research (quilt is an ongoing cal research project) and 3) gives the quilt dev team a real life situation to test. For bearmaps, it sets up a master and worker, where the master orchestrates the worker. But bearmaps, because it is not distributed, does not actually require a master. It can be set up on the worker manually. Just use the instructions from the project spec on how to run in from the command line. It involves building it with maven under the section called "Addendum for Terminal users".
Doesn't AWS only give you 750 hours free? Or is there something else I'm missing?

history.content: This might be a good question for your professor if you're unsure.

Hi! I just finished 61B last semester and I wanted to host bear maps on my own personal website. According to Stack Overflow, I need to embed the .class files in HTML. My question is, if I put the .class file in my website, would that go against university policy since someone could convert the .class file to a .java file? If so, is there any other way to host the project on my website?

Here's the Stack Overflow post: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41029236/how-do-i-embed-a-java-program-into-my-website
history.subject: Hosting bear maps on personal website
